[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_SUCCESS] [Panic vulnerability] Can the .unwrap() call in register_histogram_vec! panic during initialization if the Prometheus registry is corrupted or the metric name conflicts with existing metrics, causing the entire API tester to crash and disrupting monitoring capabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_FAIL] [Panic vulnerability] Does the .unwrap() in the API_TEST_FAIL Lazy initialization properly handle metric registration failures, or will it panic and crash the testing infrastructure when the Prometheus registry rejects duplicate metric names? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_ERROR] [Panic vulnerability] Can an attacker trigger a panic in the API_TEST_ERROR initialization by pre-registering a conflicting metric name in the global Prometheus registry, causing the .unwrap() to fail and disrupting error monitoring? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_LATENCY] [Panic vulnerability] Does the API_TEST_LATENCY Lazy initialization gracefully handle cases where Prometheus metric registration fails due to registry corruption, or will the .unwrap() cause an unrecoverable panic that halts all latency monitoring? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_STEP_LATENCY] [Panic vulnerability] Can the .unwrap() in API_TEST_STEP_LATENCY initialization be exploited through registry manipulation to cause a panic that crashes the entire API testing framework when first accessed? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_SUCCESS] [Race condition] During concurrent first access to API_TEST_SUCCESS from multiple threads, can race conditions in Lazy::new() initialization cause duplicate metric registrations or inconsistent histogram instances across threads? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_FAIL] [Race condition] If multiple threads simultaneously access API_TEST_FAIL for the first time, can the Lazy initialization race create multiple HistogramVec instances that register conflicting metrics in the Prometheus registry? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_success()] [Cardinality explosion] Can an attacker supply arbitrarily long or numerous unique test_name, network_name, or run_id values to create unlimited histogram label combinations, causing unbounded memory growth and eventual out-of-memory crashes in the metrics system? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_fail()] [Cardinality explosion] Does test_fail() validate or limit the cardinality of label combinations, or can malicious tests create millions of unique [test_name, network_name, run_id] combinations that exhaust available memory through histogram proliferation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_error()] [Cardinality explosion] Can an attacker programmatically generate high-cardinality test scenarios with unique run_id values to create excessive histogram instances in API_TEST_ERROR, leading to memory exhaustion and denial of service in the monitoring infrastructure? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_latency()] [Cardinality explosion] With four label dimensions [test_name, network_name, run_id, result], can an attacker exploit the multiplicative cardinality explosion to create O(n^4) histogram combinations that consume all available memory and crash the metrics collection system? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_step_latency()] [Cardinality explosion] Does test_step_latency() impose limits on the five-dimensional label space [test_name, step_name, network_name, run_id, result], or can attackers create exponentially growing histogram counts that exhaust memory through cardinality attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_step_latency()] [Resource exhaustion] Can malicious test suites create thousands of unique step_name values combined with dynamic run_id generation to create millions of histogram instances in API_TEST_STEP_LATENCY, causing the monitoring system to consume all available RAM and crash? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_success()] [Label injection] Can an attacker inject Prometheus label syntax characters (e.g., newlines, quotes, commas) into test_name, network_name, or run_id parameters to corrupt the metrics output format or inject malicious label-value pairs into the time series database? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_fail()] [Label injection] Does test_fail() sanitize input strings, or can attackers inject special characters like \

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_error()] [Label injection] Can test_error() accept label values containing Prometheus reserved characters that could be interpreted as metric name separators, allowing attackers to inject fake metrics or overwrite existing time series data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_latency()] [Label injection] If the result parameter in test_latency() contains unsanitized user input, can attackers inject newline characters to create additional fake metric entries in the Prometheus exposition format? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_step_latency()] [Label injection] Can attackers inject escape sequences or control characters into step_name to exploit vulnerabilities in Prometheus metric parsing, potentially causing the monitoring system to misinterpret or drop legitimate metrics? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_success()] [Input validation] Does test_success() validate that test_name, network_name, and run_id are non-empty and within reasonable length limits, or can empty strings or extremely long inputs (>10KB) cause memory issues or metrics system malfunction? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_fail()] [Input validation] Can test_fail() accept arbitrarily long string parameters that consume excessive memory when stored as Prometheus label values, potentially causing memory pressure in long-running monitoring processes? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_error()] [Input validation] Does test_error() restrict label values to valid UTF-8 strings, or can binary data or invalid UTF-8 sequences in test_name cause panics or undefined behavior in the Prometheus client library? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_latency()] [Input validation] Can the result parameter in test_latency() contain Unicode control characters or bidirectional text markers that could be exploited to create misleading or malicious-looking metric labels in monitoring dashboards? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Function: test_step_latency()] [Input validation] Does test_step_latency() validate that all five string parameters are within Prometheus label length limits (<256 characters recommended), or can excessively long labels cause performance degradation in metrics queries? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_SUCCESS] [Information disclosure] Can the API_TEST_SUCCESS histogram expose sensitive test environment details through test_name and network_name labels that reveal internal infrastructure topology or security testing strategies to unauthorized metric readers? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-api-tester/src/counters.rs] [Static: API_TEST_FAIL] [Information disclosure] Does API_TEST_FAIL inadvertently expose vulnerability patterns or security weaknesses through test failure metrics that could be scraped by attackers monitoring the public metrics endpoint? (Low)
